subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class
msgSnippet: Joe, The code that loads the file and builds the model is already in a public api (Eclipse EMF API). Thus the private method uses the public api to load and
messageBody:
Joe,

The code that loads the file and builds the model is
already in a public api (Eclipse EMF API).

Thus the private method uses the public api to load
and build the model, which is a XMI document.

However, the model component and the factory
components are specific to the method that load the
file.

So it's possible to make the pojo cleaner by using
aspects and such to separate out some concerns, but at
the end of the day you have to ask "Am I really making
this more manageable?".

So in this case we have the following:

- A public API that loads a resource and builds the
model
- The same API was used to generate model classes and
the factory components that create the model objects.
- These are used by the public API again to load the
model and create the root model instance.

So since these parts are so interrelated it makes
sense to put them in a private method and test that
method. This method is specific to the type of model
generated by EMF.

The Use Case for using the model is for 1 POJO only,
so breaking out the load code to separate concerns
adds questionable value in terms of manageability.

At the end of the day, I just wanted to make sure the
private method was working as an intermediate step to
doing a test of the public api, which is probably what
most people want to do when they test private methods.

Cheers,
- Ole



--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:

> Ilja Preuss wrote:
>
> > Ole Ersoy wrote:
> >
> > > The file loading part is in a private method,
> because
> > > the load routine is specific to the class that
> is
> > > being tested, and is therefore not useful in a
> utility
> > > library.
> >
> > Reusability is not the only reason to extract
> things into their own
> > classes, is it?
>
> Even so, Ole's perspective is a little shortsighted.
> Extracting data
> from a file consists of two operations:
>
> 1. Loading file contents into memory, usually as
> lines of text.
> 2. Parsing the lines of text while in memory.
>
> Part #1 is a perfect candidate for a reusable
> library. In Ruby, you
> simply say file.readlines(), for example. There's no
> reason to
> reimplement this the way we do in Java. (Does Java 5
> have a built-in
> library method for loading a text file yet?!)
>
> Part #2 is what's specific to your application,
> because it depends on
> how you formatted the text when you saved it. I
> could see that being a
> private method, perhaps, that takes a List of lines
> and parses them.
>
> So it might be that the only reason the "loading"
> feature is not
> reusable is that Java hasn't made the reusable part
> reusable!
